comments.commentBody:
"Other cultures, especially Latin Americans, are a lot better at accepting and enjoying the differences between the sexes, and know at an intuitive level that that these differences enrich humanity."

Gender stereotypes place disproportionate burdens on women in many Latino families. I've seen this with my (Latina) aunt and her family, and in other families Women are often expected to be self-sacrificing, even when it causes them a great deal of hardship.

My aunt comes from a family where she's the only girl, and she has three brothers. She was always expected to do a great deal of housework, whereas they were always excused because they were male. My aunt is now expected to take daily care of their elderly mother, even though she has severe health problems of her own. It's causing a huge strain on her health. Meanwhile, she has three healthy brothers who live near her mom (one of them actually lives WITH her mom, in the same house, and is unemployed). None of them lifts a hand to help her out, because it's considered her duty as a daughter.

Chewing gum would do something else that is highly beneficial: it would help kids focus better. Oral motor stimulation while listening or working helps concentration. It is one of the strategies occupational therapists suggest when trying to help children who have trouble in the classroom environment.

All children, gifted or not, disabled or not, should study music.  It's the perfect individualized course of study, as the  competition is yourself.  No one is so gifted in music that s/he can't learn more.

There is so much rich curriculum available online these days that no student should be bored in the classroom. I really think that an educational revolution is coming. My children are in public high school now and the incorporation of technological resources is so much more prevalent than even just a couple of years ago. Hang in there.

Gifted children also should study music--piano or string instrument instruction is wonderful for any young child and can absorb, like a sponge, a lot of a gifted child's potential that doesn't get optimally used at school.

Agree.  Even if odds are against it somewhat, a win there could defray an unseen loss somewhere else.  I think the poor and minorities are afraid enough of the vulture capitalist to come out in unprecedented numbers to help Obama.
If we don't have jobs because they have all gone to China -- that does not mean we need immigrants -- that explains why we don't need immigrants.

Susan,

Sure immigrants are consumers. So is the person that lost the job. If the immigrant goes home, the original workers will get the job back at an even higher wage and spend the money and pay the taxes.

And if we legalized the illegal immigrants -- they would get the Social Security benefits. the way the system is structured, low-wage workers bet very large benefits compared to their contributions. They would just be a bigger burden if we allowed them legal status.

Gene and Lester, apparently, you do not know how the game is played. The illegal workers claim a dozen dependents and get a refund bigger than all their withholdings, including Social Security and Medicare.

When they are too old to work, do you really believe America will just throw them away. Are you trying to say they can be deported when they are no longer useful as cheap labor? I cannot keep from wondering if you are employers?
Susan, there are 30 million legal workers looking for work.  Do you really think that is very few?  That is nearly 10% of the entire population.
So true.  Real liberals should also be against for environmental reasons.

A vast pool of cheap labor that won't complain certainly benefits some people. But to me, that is the argument of a Republican business man.

How it has come to be the theme song for liberals is beyond me.

Tom,

The only possible benefit to legalization is that the previously illegal workers would be guaranteed the minimum wage and overtime pay -- if they work in those industries covered by the minimum wage -- many illegals work in exempt industries. This would not give them a wage over the poverty level.

It won't get them much over $8/hr at best. Won't get them sick leave. Won't get them health or retirement benefits.

What it would do is allow them to walk into any business and say -- "I'll take any job at the minimum wage and no benefits." Then that will be the standard. Your suggestion impoverishes anyone who was doing any better.

Cheer up it could be worse Tom. And you have just told us how to make it even worse.

-- The immigrants who come here do so because the opportunities they can find are better than what is available in their home country. So, the immigrant is generally better off. And the labor force in the home country is reduced, raising wages there. Plus, the immigrants send remittances home, boosting the standard of living for those who remain behind. Any negative effect on competing workers here is certainly outweighed from a global perspective.

-- The economy is not of a fixed size, apportioned among the residents. It grows as the productive population grows. Immigrant workers create demand as well as supply. Allowing native workers to work with immigrant workers increases the number of possible skill combinations and so must increase productivity overall.

-- There are a lot of complaints about illegal immigrants in the comments. The solution, as I see it, is not to spend time and money closing our borders to those trying to chase a dream. It is to make it easier for people to enter the country legally.

-- If Americans cannot get jobs because illegal immigrants work for less than the minimum wage, then that is the fault of the minimum wage itself, which makes legal workers uncompetitive.

-- All this talk about closing borders, increasing deportations, impeding capital flows, etc., seems to me a bit defeatist. I think we should be more ambitious and work harder to compete instead of trying to defend our economic position through government intervention.

No doubt immigrants contribute to economic growth, if not always to increased productivity.  While the benefits may accrue to the private sector, the costs however are in the public sector.  Much of the social cost is born by our schools and that additional cost can extend through several generations.   This is especially true of those immigrants imbued with an agrarian culture where education is not always valued and expectations diminished.  If we are to have a sustainable immigration policy, it must be based on the long term welfare of all Americans.

Every country was "built" by immigrants. What has that got to do with public policy? The essence of the United States is that its society was built on an English idea of freedom and fair play. The success of the US results from a combination of culture, inability of early settlers to set up an extractive society, and the enormous resources of a nearly empty land (after the natives were killed off, which is not something to be proud of). The land has not been empty for nearly a hundred years, and population has reached the point of diminishing returns for quality of life. Almost all of the population increase since 1970 is due to excessive immigration. Most people who object to more immigration are objecting to numbers, not immigrants. Look it up at NumbersUSA.org

"Money is taken out of their wages, but the aliens themselves do not qualify for these benefits, and so never withdraw the money they've deposited into the system."

Are you saying we can deport them when they are too old to be used for cheap labor?

As others have said, it is hard to respond to the various points in this article because the author went back and forth between illegal immigration and legal immigration, both in what he said himself and the statistics he cited.

But here are a few points:

1. Don't think only illegal immigrants are poorly educated and in lower-paid jobs. Many of the legal immigrants we take in the same boat. What makes them different is that they have a relative here to sponsor them.

So our people who are high school dropouts and high school graduates face lots of immigrant competition for the few jobs out there that are available.

2. If we train our political, business, religious and education leaders to think that America can't function without a high number of immigrants and that native workers are too demanding and therefore undesirable, that is what they will believe and they will act accordingly.

We can already see that happening. As crazy and stupid as it is, we have millions of Americans who support this anti-American worker PR blitz.

3. Many of the people who support more immigration may someday see their own job go to a foreign worker -- either an immigrant here or a worker still overseas.

Will their own job loss or that of a close family member or relative finally make them see that there is no such thing, really, as "cheap foreign labor" when all of the costs are considered?

We'll see.

John -- Unemployment benefits are 1/2 of prior salary; in your example the displaced worker must have been making $20 an hour. So there was actually a net savings to society of $4 an hour. The new employee's wages would have to be more than 1/2 of the displaced worker's for there to be a net cost.

I'm sure you could construct a better example with this in mind; however, aren't you pointing out an issue with unemployment insurance and not immigration? The same issue would arise if the employee had been displaced by a young American just entering the workforce, or by someone moving up from a lower-paying job.

Unemployment insurance is intended to tide the displaced worker over until he/she is able to find a new job. Therefore, increased UI payments should only be an issue in the short run. And aren't UI payroll taxes supposed to fund the program? (I do realize that it is not always so easy to get a comparable new job, and that extended benefits may allow displaced workers to continue receiving payments for quite a while.)

The economist also ignores the costs of social services given to the $6 an hour worker and his family, that Americans would not use.  U.S, taxpayers are subsidizing immigrant labor through hospital emergency room health care, schools,  food stamps, CHIP programs, etc.

Let's say that an immigrant takes a job for $6 an hour, displacing an American worker.  We the taxpayers pay the displaced worker let's say $10 an hour in unemployment benefits.  How can we as a society be benefitting from the supposed cheap labor when it is actually costing us $16 an hour?  We are not seeing the true effects on the balance sheet because the government is borrowing the $10 an hour in deficit spending.

Dan,

If they lose their jobs to e-verify, the employer would need to hire an American or legal immigrant. Mission accomplished!

Dan, Why don't you have any compassion for poor Americans?

Interesting study, but lacking consideration for how humans can work vs a machine.  Humans need breaks between tasks, thinking time, bathroom breaks, etc..  So while the specific tasks may have only taken nn amount of hours, the rest are still "work" hours nonetheless.

Outside of people who own their own business, whenever I hear someone tell me they work 70 plis hour weeks, I never believe them.  These 70 hour week workers always show up after 9AM and are often the ones who never ever get anything done.

Mr. Hollande is either delusional or  he's convinced that by remaining positive he will somehow magically solve the crisis. I doubt anyone's fooled. The Germans don't want to be on the hook for debt of their Euro brethren, and they don't want many of their banks open to the perusal of Euro outsiders. I don't see that changing in the short term. Whatever actions they agree to in the long term may not matter.

"I believe the number 1 biggest problem in the world today is OVERPOPULATION."

Marilyn Vos Savant, worlds highest IQ since 1958

The assumption underlying right wing economic thought, as demonstrated in this post, is that businesses would be delighted to help people by giving them jobs, except that these employers are "uncertain" about the potential impact upon them of taxes and regulations endlessly imposed by a feckless government.
In fact, the default position is more often quite the opposite, especially in today's labor environment in which unions are irrelevant if present at all, a large proportion of workers are ineligible for overtime pay, and workers are reluctant to challenge employers over long hours. In other words, only when employers are uncertain that they can obtain a desired level of production from their worker and start to worry about meeting customer demand do they resort to hiring additional workers.
I'll check back when there are specifics until then it is like spitting in the wind.

Just in case anybody's still reading, I thought this Saturday was tough but fair. CIN was also my final fill, and I had to read it about 10 times before the lightbulb went on.

Gotta include a link to "ANY DAY NOW," a classic R&B/pop hit from 1962, by Chuck Jackson. Dig that organ riff.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9_OS04Sn1Oo
Stockman is distancing himself from one fairy tale only to attach himself to another.  Bartlett is sounding like a man above fairy tales.  I credit Bartlett a lot more than Stockman.
